review.title: Logic of temporal attribute implications
review.abstract: We study logic for reasoning with if-then formulas describing dependencies between attributes of objects which are observed in consecutive points in time. We introduce semantic entailment of the formulas, show its fixed-point characterization, investigate closure properties of model classes, present an axiomatization and prove its completeness, and investigate alternative axiomatizations and normalized proofs. We investigate decidability and complexity issues of the logic and prove NP-hardness of the entailment problem. We show that by restricting to predictive formulas, the entailment problem is decidable in pseudo-linear time.

metadata.title: Logic of temporal attribute implications

sections.text: ar Xiv: 141 2.36 33v2 [cs.LO] We examine thinking logic with if-then formulas that describe dependencies between features of objects observed in successive time periods. We introduce semantic sequences of formulas, show their fixed point characterization, examine closure properties of model classes, represent an axiomatization and prove their completeness, and examine alternative axiomatizations and normalized proofs. We examine determinability and complexity problems of logic, and prove that the closure problem is NP-hard and belongs to EXPSPACE. We show that by limiting ourselves to predictive formulas, the closure problem can be decided in pseudo-linear time.Keywords: attributimplication, complete axiomatization, entanglement problem, fixed point, functional dependence, temporal semantics.

sections.text: Logic expands the classical logic for dealing with if-then-rules by taking discrete points of time as an additional component. We have investigated both the semantic entanglement, which is based on maintaining validity in models at all points of time, and the syntactical entanglement, which is represented by a relation of evidence. We have shown a characterization of semantic entanglement, which is based on the fewest models and the syntactic-semantic completeness of logic.
